bugs.title: CVE-2024-38517 rapidjson: privilege escalation via integer underflow in GenericReader::ParseNumber() [fedora-all]

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2024-38517 rapidjson: privilege escalation via integer underflow in GenericReader::ParseNumber() [fedora-all]

blocked.short_desc: CVE-2024-38517 rapidjson: privilege escalation via integer underflow in GenericReader::ParseNumber()

long_desc.thetext: Tencent RapidJSON is vulnerable to privilege escalation due to an integer underflow in the `GenericReader::ParseNumber()` function of `include/rapidjson/reader.h` when parsing JSON text from a stream. An attacker needs to send the victim a crafted file which needs to be opened; this triggers the integer underflow vulnerability (when the file is parsed), leading to elevation of privilege.

More information about this security flaw is available in the following bug:

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2296854

Disclaimer: Community trackers are created by Red Hat Product Security team on a best effort basis. Package maintainers are required to ascertain if the flaw indeed affects their package, before starting the update process.

For the benefit of people that aren't psychic https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2024-38517 is the issue in question.

That in turn links to https://github.com/Tencent/rapidjson/pull/1261 which is the actual upstream report/fix and which is six years old so I'm not sure why somebody has decided it's a pants-on-fire matter now.

Sadly because upstream are a complete pain in the arse that still hasn't been released as there have been no new releases for eight years now.
